> WHY THE FUCK IS JHIN BALANCED AROUND LETHALITY????

This is the question that needs to be answered.

Jhin's power is greatly tied to lethality, and the reason for that is mathematically simple. For right now, let us assume that one statement, "Jhin's power is tied to lethality" is true. I will demonstrate why this is at the end, but for starters we need to make the argument.

Now, if we can assume that Jhin becomes stronger as lethality becomes stronger, and we can assume that Jhin becomes weaker as lethality becomes weaker, then we can also see an important point: if we simply buff Jhin's kit directly while lethality is weak, then Jhin may become playable, but if lethality is ever improved for another reason, Jhin becomes too strong. 

For example, if Jhin is performing at 46% right now while building lethality, and we buff Jhin's kit so that he's performing at 50% while building lethality, that might be good for Jhin players. However, that would mean that if we buff lethality itself later because Talon or Zed is underperforming, then Jhin's win rate will increase above 50% while building lethality. That makes sense, right?

With that said, if Jhin is too weak and lethality items also look a bit weak, it makes more sense to simply buff the items knowing that that will buff Jhin because he primarily builds those items, rather than just buffing Jhin.

Now for the second part. Why is Jhin's kit so directly tied with lethality, when Jhin has more critical strike components than anyone else in the game. There are a number of reasons for this, but the most important reason is that Jhin's passive, Death in Four Acts, has an execute on it. This execute is likely intended to help Jhin farm effectively with only four autos per reload, and also serves as an interesting harass pattern. 

If Jhin attacks someone while he has 300 AD, that AD does not directly improve his % missing health damage component. It does help him get their health lower for the fourth hit, but the fourth hit itself will deal only 300 + 25% of the target's missing health. 25% is an extreme amount, by the way. Many assassins only get 8% of a target's missing health, Jhin has triple that and it costs no mana and has no cooldown.

However, if Jhin attacks someone while he has lethality, that DOES increase the % missing health component, because it reduces the target's ability to resist the damage, making it closer to true damage. That's the reason why Jhin builds lethality and sees success with it. His % missing health damage in A Death in Four Acts is likely the largest amount of damage in his entire kit, and it has no AD ratio, cannot crit, and does not benefit from attack speed. So you build lethality. That's all there is to it.

Because other than any other ADC in the game, Jhin does not profit from Attack Speed in any relevant way (Even Graves at least gets his reload timers shortened), sooooo, Genius Riot had another plan :-)

I don't get it either.
Jhin is just fine with crit.

The only issue I could honestly see is crit ADCs do better than him thanks to not being locked by attack speed.
Jhin can lifesteal back in bigger bursts, but crit ADCs do a hefty bit of damage too (around 2 autos deals the same damage as one of his), and they can attack a lot faster meaning they can _effectively_ lifesteal a lot faster. Around one of Jhin's autoattacks will deal upwards of 80-90% of a squishy's health, but if they can hit back 4-6+ times and kill him in that duration or lifesteal back enough to survive the second, they will win the trade.

Not being able to attack for 2.5 seconds in lategame is a huge hamper too, but one of the biggest reasons he's balanced.

Jhin is undoubtedly strong at full build, it's just other crit ADCs beat him at that.
But Lucian, MF, and others beat him at the armorpen/shred game which is the other side of it.

He's sort of this weird half-and-half in the middle tbh.

Except that crit is too late-game based in a game where early and mid game is almost everything.

If crit isn't "THE late game stat" then a lot of crit champs, not just Jhin, would also be stronger.

ADC's and the absurd amount of heals and shields are a major problem currently. Buffing lethality is a way to buff champions that are currently struggling in this meta and will tone down ADC's current power by giving the counters a chance to actually counter them. 

AD Assassins simply don't have enough damage to eat through all the peel, shields, and absurd damage ADC's are putting out and drain tanking with this new deaths dance and Lifesteal mastery. Or, in the case of certain assassins, I.E rengar, they no longer are played as an assassin and are now a bruiser, trying to dive in, get damage, then die hoping their carries can finish off the enemy carries. It's a god damn clusterfuck of a mess.

This is going to help the game rather than hurt it, cause God knows when ADC's and Supports are getting banned over other champions you know the games a mess.

Did Riot have those two in mind when Lethality launched?

She doesn't scale well in general and lethality gives her the better early game she needs. Jayce sure doesn't build lethality that much anymore but the lethality gives his poke the necessary damage to forfill his role.

I feel like Jayce's poke would be fine without Lethality.

As for Quinn, introducing/adjusting her scaling to support a normal Marksman build would be fine. The main goal, after all, is to avoid the fiasco when Lethality launched where ranged champions were OP with it.

When lethality was launched it was fine for most of the time, it wasn't until they stupidly buffed it in patch 7.3 where things started to get out of hand. It wasn't even just the lethality stat itself that was the issue, it was the edge of night active that was the biggest offender. If marksmen had crit synergy like xayah then lethality would be less of a problem, glad riot is doing that with kindred now too. 

For real though I love the lethality items on Quinn and not just for the lethality stat, the out of combat movement speed and item actives actually gave her a proper role in league as a roaming assassin and it would be a shame if it was removed.

They buffed the Lethality items because they were underperforming on the melee assassins that were meant to build them (Kha'Zix, Talon, Zed, Rengar, etc).

ADCs using them came out of nowhere, just like when they started using Sterak's Gage.

Quinn may be a marksman due to her powerful ranged auto attacks, but her primary combat pattern more closely resembles that of an assassin's due to her high target selection, burst damage, and mobility. [Riot acknowledged this when Lethality items were first launched](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/developer-corner/pt97eEjE-duskblade-ad-assassins-and-you?comment=00120000) -- she's definitely on the list of champions they intend to benefit from Lethality.

Crit _works_ on Quinn, sure -- and the crit-based mechanic you see on her passive today was given to her during the Marksman Update to ensure it wouldn't be too terrible of a purchase -- but it by no means serves Quinn's purposes as a champion as well as Lethality does; she's a squishy ranged assassin whose primary combat tool forces her straight into melee range of an enemy, so you can imagine why an item like Edge of Night might be so important on her.
I'd argue that adcs need to benefit more from crit or just be balanced around lethality as a main build.
Riot already made crit items cheaper man. What else can we do beyond reworking it entirely?

Perhaps tie up more of their ability scalings in the actual crit stat?

Xayah is a good showcase of this, a fair amount of her E damage is tied up in crit, and building lethality/arpen will come at the cost to that damage.
Ashe has slows or damage tied to her crit but she still builds botrk.

There is a difference between taking one item away from crit, and building entirely around a different stat (Lethality).  When Lethality builds were the thing, they were building all 3 lethality items, LW, and Cleaver.  They were completely forgoing AS and Crit entirely to stack more Lethality generally.

Further more, Bork takes the place of BT in many builds, meaning that you are really just trading AD for AS and on hit damage.

How about:

1. Nerf overall basic-hit lethality by half
2. Add passive that spells and abilities have doubled lethality (which means as much lethality as now)

Suddenly auto-attacking ADCs don't benefit from lethality as much

I suppose if we reduced base attack speed of ADCs and increased the AS of their crit items, lethality could become a less viable option for a carry.

Other than that, we could reduce AD ratios across the board and create more reliance on crit and attack speed for ADCs.
